title: How should I prepare for the SAT in 2 months? - Quora

response.answer_text: Study. Religiously. All the time. Intensely. Don’t put it off, and work your butt off on it. I took the SAT at the end of Freshman year. I scored decent (1420) but I knew I could do better. I took it two more times, imrpoving to a 1470 and then a 1520. But I never studied. I never looked over what I should have. As a result, I improved in English (which I became better at because of living in the US) but I decreased in my Math score (from a 770 to 720). Then came the January of Junior year. I was signed up to take (my last) SAT for the purpose of taking the SAT essay during May. But I wanted to score well. So well. So I studied. I got the SAT book and cranked out a math test every week. Then I studied with online videos. It was really easy, as I was finishing my Calculus BC class at the time. The math wasn’t an issue- it was formulaic. And when the test came, i felt fantastic. I ended up getting a perfect math score. 1550, thanks to my previously improved english score. But it only came because of studying. I couldn’t do it by walking in and winging it, even though I know so many friends who did just that. I used the same technique to self-study my butt off for the Math 2 subject test (780) and Molecular Biology (750). I don’t think I would get over a 700 without spending a month in the practice books. I also tutor the SAT nowadays. I find a lot of people need someone to help them, either to review concepts they have long since forgotten, or to teach them the ways of smart test-taking. Consider finding a tutor if that floats your boat. And yes, it’s just a test. Other things will weigh more heavily on your application. But you seem to care about the test, so please take the care to do well. And if you don’t perform your best this time? Take it again. Superscoring does wonders.

YES, very much feasible. You just need about 100+ hours of preparation to ace the test. That can definitely be achieved within 2 months range, even though ideally three months will be a good time. Please review SAT in detail to understand the content / syllabus for each section of the SAT exam. Even if you had taken SAT, it will be helpful if you revisit this and review if any section you had missed out, etc. Refer Which books are the best to prepare for the SAT preparation? and select one for your preparation. I would personally recommend Barron’s. It is a bit harder than the actual SAT, but it is better to write a harder mock test than the easier one. So if you are in a time constraint, don’t get demotivated by the mock test results. You can conclude SAT preparation, by taking Official SAT Practice Tests, published by College Board, one by one and try completing all of them. This gives you practice to remain concentrated for full exam duration and also help you in bridging the knowledge gap. Practice makes you perfect and also gets you used to the rigor of actual test. Take the most recent one, answer as if you are doing in a test center and within the prescribed time. Evaluate your answers, you have scoring sheet and also explanations to answers available.Review all wrong / guessed questions and understand how you can get them right next time. Take the next practice test, adopt this iterative approach, until you complete all official tests and will definitely improve your overall score.

With dedication and diligence, two months is sufficient for preparing for the SAT. There are many factors involved such as the starting score and the ideal score that the test-taker wishes to achieve. Nevertheless, following a proven SAT program or any well self structured program, any test taker can make improvements on the SAT within two months. The higher the test-taker initially scores, the harder it will be to improve. It is much more difficult to improve from a 1550 to 1600, compared to improving from a 1000 to a 1050 due to the amount of knowledge and luck needed to score a 1600. Simply put, it is possible to prepare for the SAT in two months, and the lower the beginner initially scores, the more they can potentially improve with time. Of course, with a two month time limit, one cannot expect to improve from a 1000 to a 1550. Therefore, any type of improvement that can be made will be relative to the initial score. My estimates for improvement with two months of good practice. 1000 -> 1200 1200 -> 1350 1350 -> 1450 1450 ->1500 Disclaimer: This content is based off of my prior experiences, results may vary.

I think 3 months is a good time for studying for SAT. I know of students who have cracked it within 1 month as well. To ensure that your preparation is very effective, you should prepare a plan. List down all the areas of SAT and put them in these 3 buckets: Excellent: No help or preparation neededGood: Little brushing up needed along with some help and practiceNot good: Need lot of help and practice.The last bucket is the most critical one and you should focus most upon. It is important that you ideally get hold some good tutor for these areas who has knowledge of SAT. If the in-person ones are too expensive, then you can go for online SAT tutoring. There are multiple companies that provide this, but one such reputed one is called eTutorWorld. The best part about them is that they will help you make a plan for 3 months with complete personal attention. All the sessions will be 1-to-1 personalized and customized based on your need. Maybe it’s a good idea to get started by taking a free trial lesson with them and then making a call. in the free trial, you can very clearly mention that you are looking for SAT prep help.

Hello Sure, it is possible. Take an official practice test from Khan Academy to see your beginning score. Determine the score you want or need. Begin reading The Atlantic articles. Read them on your phone or print some out and put in your bookbag. They have a written flow that really feels good as you read them. Their articles are interesting, too. That's going to help you with the reading, writing, and grammar for the test. There is much more to the planning of your study schedule, but essentially the key is to take time to learn what you did wrong on your wrong questions and what you did right on your correct questions of your practice tests. Even if you only learn one or two new concepts, it will make more of a difference than you think. Don't time yourself until you have increased the number of problems on a practice test that you get correct by, say, 10% of your original score. Write down each of the math and grammar mistakes you make and re-solve each problem a day later, and then a week later. Do not take any new practice tests within 7 days of your SAT. Just rework a few of the same problems and questions you already took. Relax the day before the SAT. If you are not satisfied with your score, study more, and retake the SAT a second time. Most students do. Good luck.

3 months is actually a long time for SAT preparation. Buy a book or 2, create an account on Khan Academy (an excellent tool that helped me immensely) and do A LOT of practice tests. Initially, start with the basics: revise some grammar, vocabulary and basic Math, move on to more advanced topics and make sure to develop a lucid understanding regarding the test format itself. SAT is all about strategy and time management. You must really learn to focus and maintain that focus for long periods of time. To do that, every day should be filled with some kind of SAT-related activity (read a text, solve a problem or 2,…) You should really intensify your practice at the second month and ease up at the end. Khan Academy is a website that allows you to create your own daily practice schedule which you monitor and you adjust according to your needs. Use whatever tool you have at your disposal and you’ll be fine. Good luck.

The key word here is “possible.” However, in my instruction of thousands of students, I would argue it’s not easy in those short months for the majority. I just read an answer from someone who scored 800 and the high 700’s. For those elite students who have the capability to score that high, I would say yes. However, the majority scores much lower. The majority has weaker English skills. The majority is just plain average. Thus, being the majority or average. I would argue it’s a good 2–3 years for a beginner to do well. And that’s with diligent effforts. However, for the elite of top test takers, yes 2 months is possible. P.s. you also just ask about whether you can prepare. Obviously, you can prepare, but the question is loaded and you meant to probably say “do well.” Who doesn’t think that when asking questions here about the exams?

Yes. I recommend going through the Official SAT Study Guide provided by the Collegeboard.Focus on your weakest areasAlthough it's uncomfortable working on weaknesses it's the only thing that can dramatically higher your scoreTake timed and untimed practice tests at home (especially if you usually have some difficulty with finishing tests at school)Do research on how to get the highest score possiblePrepscholar is a good place to look for adviceSearch things like “how to get a [goal score] in the [your weaker area] section”If you haven't taken the SAT yet take a practice test under the usual time constraints of a REAL SAT and see how you scored.From there you can gauge your goal score from thereAlways do your best! ALWAYS go back and check your answers if you have time. Hope this helped! Have fun with the SAT! Be confident, you've been training for this your whole life and you didn't even know it.

Yes. I’ve found that students generally do well with at least 2 months prep. Having good practice questions are key. Students that have the most success are the ones who efficiently study using resources that provide immediate feedback and target areas to improve. The way you practice and the quality of the resources you use is vital to your preparation. One thing that makes UWorld unique is our authors spend most of their time explaining concepts in a simple, clear and easy to understand way.

Well..!!.. This depends on your current level. If you would have shared your current scores then, it would have been easier for me to tell you the strategy to prepare for the exam in the remaining period. Since you haven’t mentioned anything then. I will be general here. Analyze the recent mock test that you took.Once done with the first step then, try to figure out your weaker areas and see whether you made those mistakes consistently, or not.Work out those mistakes and try not to repeat those mistakes.Once you feel confident then take up the mock test and see whether you have improved or not.Gradually, increase the number of mock tests and if you are consistently getting good scores then consider yourself as fully prepared for the exam.I hope you got the answer. Note: I am associated with Achievers’ Point.

It all depends on what your background has been up to this point. Get a copy of some practice exams. Just go to SAT Practice Tests and try some out. Then see how ready you feel. The regular SAT isn’t something you can cram for. It’s a measure of what you’ve been doing for years. The practice exams help you gt a feel for areas in which you may need more practice. If you are thinking of the SAT Subject Tests, two months is a good brushup time but not if you aren’t already strong in the subject. Good luck, and thanks for the A2A.

Google: commonly appearing vocabulary words for the SAT. Count the number of words you must learn divided by the number of days remaining before the test. Now you know how many words you should learn daily. Buy the prep book from any book store. Familiarity with the format will improve your grade. Administer one test following guidelines so you know what your needs are test wise. Follow the procedures the prep book outlines. Try to take a class on line. Some educators feel the SAT should be completely eliminated this spring and summer. If your school district has eliminated on campus SAT prep cl Continue Reading

Yes, if you work hard and concentrate on studying by sticking to a concrete plan then you should be fine. Two months is more than enough for the SAT on an average student. Many people only use a month to get ready, but there are many factors involved including how long you are studying every single day and how prepared you are now. You can take a practice test to determine this. Good luck!

I think 2 months should be enough if you prepare well. First of all, join an exam prep program, they can guide you the correct way, with the correct material and such. Manya-The Princeton Review is pretty good for SAT coaching, they are one of the most reputed names in this business, so they can really guide you the right way. Otherwise, you can look for other options to see what suits you.

If you have money go take a coaching class for it. If you don’t, “Khan Academy” and the official college board papers will be more than enough…. For English punctuation and grammar “Reason Prep” has an awesome FREE course…. Rprep’s other courses are really good too and way cheaper than the other Prep companies out there… Here are the Links— SAT & ACT Prep and Videos (reason prep) Practice (College board practice tests) Khan Academy Please upvote and follow if you like the answer!

Assuming that you are an international student. You have your SAT in December so it gives you roughly two months to prepare. It’s more than enough time. I will recommend studying 2–3 hours a day. Focus on your week points. For practice go to http://khanacadameny.org and you can use book sby various publishers . Don’t just practice blindly but see where you are going wrong & try to understand and eliminate your errors.

First of all it's SAT not sat.  Prepare from bluebook , the official study guide for SAT by college board. After that you can start working on other books , e.g. Barron's , kaplan , TPR etc.  Let me tell you , SAT ,  unlike JEE ,  judges you on the basis of your basics , rather than your mugging power or like your ability to do horrendous questions based on terrifying formulas. Get your basic english cleared , and you're good to go. Good luck!

Even though I recommend preparing for the SAT from 4–4.5 months before, the learning period varies according to your ability and 1.5–2 months is pretty good for preparation. I would say, revise your concepts well, then complete one practice test, analyze your mistakes, rectify them, and repeat. I revised my concepts from Khan Academy and subscribed to their 20 questions per day program and solved tests from CollegeBoard, Barron’s and McGraw Hill. It would be better if you buy a SAT book, preferably Barron’s if you are aiming for 1500 and above.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Ano Nym Ous

response.answer_text: Only buy the college board blue book and just do questions of 4 practice tests. And take a real time paper test with remaining 4. Do not do other books as you can get a wrong impression of what is gonna come, if you do all 4 congrats now focus on which you are weak and improve that.
Yes. Let's review a chart of possible SAT study times.
Yes, but it depends on the person and access to materials and desire to learn. It’s just as possible as learning anything else in that time period.

Get the blue book, and do as many practice tests as you'd like. Read the rules for the grammar section (really 5 basic ones), and then some vocab for the CR close to the test. For general CR, just do a few practice tests.
